title: Between the Pages
subtitle: A day in the life of Emily Roberts, senior book specialist at Melbourne's premier literary department store.

cards.text: There was a small breeze when Emily came out for her lunch as she usually did, even when it was raining, instead of going up to the store canteen. You could never get a table to yourself there, and whoever sat with you always wanted to complain about the shop, the customers, the management or the canteen food. Everyone at Harrison's seemed to have a complaint of some kind, although it was one of the best Sydney stores to work for, and many of the staff had been there for years – some of them were long past retiring age. This was because the management let them stay on when they were really past it, like poor old Thomas, who was always trying to sell people designs that would look old for them.

cards.text: Emily herself had been in the book department for more than four years. She had started as a junior, knocking over piles of books and breaking the till once a week in her efforts to serve customers quickly. Now she was Head Salesperson and moved calmly around the department between the bright new paperbacks, knowing where every book was, what the people who 'stampeded' through the shop with never a moment to spare would be looking for before they could find someone to take their money.

cards.text: She knew every book in the place, and all about the new ones before they came out. She was said to be Mr Davies's right-hand person – and heaven knows she liked him, though she was sometimes asked into his office to meet a favoured publisher's representative. The book department, partly due to Mr Davies's weak administration, but partly because it was thought to be sophisticated, was the only department in Harrison's where you did not have to wear black. This led to some confusion as to who was an assistant, not atypical of bookshops, and accounted for the distressed look of people who picked up a book they wanted but were afraid that someone would grab it for the store detective before they could find someone to take their money.

cards.text: Emily was wearing her grey suit today. She had liked the grey suit. She had liked it for a long time, because she had accepted her aunt's advice that it was too classy an expensive suit that would last them to keep her in any suits that looked very smart for a few weeks, until they began to wrinkle at the elbows and sag at the seams, and turned round in the street to look at it, but it would stand having its skirt taken up or let down according to the whim of fashion.

cards.text: Christine liked her work, as much as one can like any job that imprisons one from nine till five-thirty. She liked Harrison's, but she was always glad to get out into the street, even though it meant queuing for a table at one of the restaurants and teashops that the local shop-workers. Here people tended to eat with one eye on their watches and had a taste for things like pasta and puddings which were the most filling at the least cost. But Emily, once seated, enjoyed a leisurely, well-chosen meal. As she worked in the book department, where customers liked to take their time, unlike the people who stampeded through the other parts of the shop with never a moment to spare. Emily had been at the standing for. She liked her authority in the book department. Sometimes, quietly, she immensely wondered how she liked its relation to the rest of the world. At Harrison's there was jealousy.

There were no prices on the books.

cards.text: Also, when she was her junior, was always meeting people at lunchtime. Even if it was exciting, like an adventure. Alice and the other junior, Helen, were always giggling in the classics section where the air was not enough. If Emily came along, they would suddenly look serious and pretend to be straightening books. Emily thought she should leave them feel very old. Her twenty-six years might have been at the dodging age. She liked her authority in the book department.
